problems.problem_statement: A synchronous buck converter operates with Vin=12V, Vout=3.3V, L=4.7μH, C=47μF, and fsw=500kHz. The load current is 5A. (a) Calculate the duty cycle. (b) Calculate the inductor current ripple. (c) Calculate the output voltage ripple assuming ideal capacitor.

Design a boost converter for a solar MPPT application with the following specifications: Vin=15-25V (panel voltage range), Vout=48V (battery), Pout=200W, fsw=100kHz, maximum inductor current ripple=30% of average.

A flyback converter operates with Vin=48V, Vout=5V, fsw=100kHz, Np:Ns=6:1, Lm=100μH (referred to primary). (a) Determine the duty cycle for CCM operation. (b) Find the boundary load resistance for CCM/DCM transition. (c) Calculate output voltage ripple if C=100μF and Iout=2A in CCM.

A buck-boost converter supplies a 10Ω load from a 24V source. The output voltage is -18V. Switching frequency is 50kHz and L=200μH. (a) Find the duty cycle. (b) Verify CCM operation. (c) Calculate average input current.

A forward converter with reset winding has Vin=48V, Vout=5V, Iout=10A, fsw=150kHz, transformer ratio Np:Ns:Nr=8:1:8. (a) Calculate maximum duty cycle. (b) Find required output inductance for 40% ripple current. (c) Determine transformer volt-seconds.

solution.part_b: D_actual = Ns*Vout/Vin = 1*5/6 = 0.833? Wait, D = n*Vout/Vin where n=Np/Ns=8. D = Vout*n/Vin = 5*8/48 = 0.833. But D_max=0.5. So D=Vout*Np/(Vin*Ns) = 5*8/(48*1) ≈ 0.83 > 0.5. Need to verify: Vout = D*Vin/n = D*48/8 = 6*D. For Vout=5V: D = 5*8/48 = 0.833. This exceeds D_max!
solution.part_c: For valid design: Vout ≤ D_max*Vin/n = 0.5*48/8 = 3V. The specs have an issue.

answers.note: Problem specs may need adjustment for forward converter constraints

problems.problem_statement: A buck converter has: Vin=24V, Vout=5V, Iout=5A, fsw=300kHz, L=22μH with DCR=15mΩ, C=220μF with ESR=20mΩ. Calculate: (a) Output voltage ripple from capacitance. (b) Output voltage ripple from ESR. (c) Total output ripple (approximate).

Design an inductor for a boost converter: L=47μH, IL_peak=8A, IL_rms=6A. Core: EE25 with Ae=52mm², AL=160nH/turn², Bsat=0.3T. Calculate: (a) Minimum turns. (b) Wire gauge for J=5A/mm². (c) Check saturation.

solution.part_a: N = sqrt(L/AL) = sqrt(47μ/160n) = sqrt(294) = 17.1, use N=18
solution.part_c: B = L*IL_peak/(N*Ae) = 47μ*8/(18*52e-6) = 0.40T > 0.3T, SATURATES! Need more turns or larger core.

problems.problem_statement: A buck converter MOSFET has: Coss=100pF, Qg=15nC, tr=15ns, tf=10ns. Operating at Vds=24V, Id=5A, fsw=500kHz, Vgate=10V. Calculate: (a) Turn-on switching loss. (b) Turn-off switching loss. (c) Gate drive loss. (d) Total switching losses.
Design an input LC filter for a buck converter: Vin=48V, Vout=12V, Iout=4A, fsw=200kHz. Requirements: corner frequency at fsw/10, damping factor ζ=0.5.

solution.step2: Choose Lf first. For ζ=0.5: R_damp = 2*ζ*sqrt(Lf/Cf)

problems.problem_statement: A buck converter with Vin=24V, fsw=500kHz has switch rise time tr=20ns. (a) Estimate the bandwidth of switching noise. (b) Calculate the fundamental switching noise frequency. (c) Estimate dV/dt stress.

Design a complete synchronous buck converter: Vin=12V, Vout=1.8V, Iout=15A, fsw=600kHz. Specify: (a) Duty cycle. (b) Inductor value for 30% ripple. (c) Output capacitor for 30mV ripple (include ESR=5mΩ). (d) Estimate efficiency with Rds_on=5mΩ per MOSFET.

solution.part_c: ΔVout_target = 30mV. ΔVESR = ΔIL*ESR = 4.5*0.005 = 22.5mV. ΔVC = sqrt(30²-22.5²) = 19.8mV. C = ΔIL/(8*f*ΔVC) = 4.5/(8*600k*0.0198) = 47μF

problems.problem_statement: For a 48V to 3.3V/30A converter, compare flyback, forward, and half-bridge topologies. Specify preferred topology and justify based on: power level, efficiency, complexity, and cost.

solution.flyback: Suitable up to ~100W, single switch, higher RMS currents, moderate efficiency (85-88%)
solution.forward: Better for 50-200W, two switches (active clamp) or reset winding, good efficiency (88-92%)
solution.half_bridge: Better for 100-500W, four switches, higher complexity, highest efficiency (92-95%)
solution.recommendation: Forward converter with active clamp - good balance of efficiency, complexity, and cost at this power level

problems.problem_statement: A boost converter has: Vin=5V, L=10μH, fsw=1MHz, R_load=50Ω. (a) Find critical duty cycle for CCM/DCM boundary. (b) Calculate output voltage at D=0.3 assuming CCM. (c) Verify the mode of operation.

solution.part_c: K = D*(1-D)² for boost boundary. At D=0.3: K_required = 0.3*0.49 = 0.147 < 0.4. CCM operation confirmed.

problems.problem_statement: Design a transformer for a push-pull converter: Vin=24V, Vout=5V, Iout=20A, fsw=100kHz. Core: ETD34, Ae=97mm², Bmax=0.2T. Calculate turns ratio and primary/secondary turns.

solution.step1: Vout = 2*D*Vin/n, assume D_max=0.45, n = 2*D*Vin/Vout = 2*0.45*24/5 = 4.32, use n=4
solution.step3: Ns = Np/n = 3/4 = 0.75, not practical. Use Np=4, Ns=1

problems.problem_statement: A voltage-mode buck converter has: Vin=12V, Vout=3.3V, L=4.7μH, C=100μF, R=1.65Ω, fsw=500kHz. (a) Find LC resonant frequency. (b) Estimate required crossover frequency. (c) Calculate required compensator gain at crossover.

solution.part_b: f_c = fsw/10 to fsw/5 = 50-100kHz. Use f_c = 50kHz
solution.part_c: At f_c, plant gain ≈ Vin*(f_LC/f_c)² = 12*(7.34/50)² = 0.26. Compensator must provide 1/0.26 = 3.85 gain
